report_title: Concert and Event Promotion Industry Report
executive_summary: Concert and event promoters produce, advertise and manage a variety of live events and performances, including concerts, sporting events and public appearances. During the last few years, industry revenue has experienced significant growth. Positive economic expansion fueled consumer discretionary purchases on live events and related performances. In 2020, the outbreak of COVID-19 led to over 47.0% revenue decline, creating an unprecedented disruption for the industry. In the latter half of 2021, the easing of COVID-19 restrictions boosted demand for live events, leading to a year of record-level recovery.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Quarantine Measures in Response to COVID-19 Halted Virtually All Industry Activity
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic created unprecedented turmoil because of the unique nature of the virus and the public health response it demanded. Since COVID-19 is highly contagious, the primary tactic to reduce the spread was to quarantine and follow social distancing mandates, leading to the cancellation of concerts and large events.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Recovery Was Swift Following Mass Vaccination Efforts
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Under the condition that venues require proof of vaccination, state and local governments enabled industry operators to resume event promoting in 2021, which led to extremely high turnout rates across the country that year. Substantial and record-level revenue growth is a direct result of the release of pent-up demand for events following the end of pandemic restrictions.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Lack of Experienced Employees as a Result of Labor Shortages
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: There is a significant shortage of experienced tour and show techs, so promoters have been forced to turn to inexperienced and poorly trained employees to fill the void at many event locations. This scarcity can result in increased workloads for existing staff, potential delays in organizing events and a higher risk of errors or oversights.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Technology Has Helped Promotors Expand Their Reach to New Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Digital ticketing platforms like Eventbrite and Ticketmaster have gained prominence by establishing exclusivity contracts with venues, in addition to developing their interfaces. QR codes and mobile apps now streamline entry and enhance security. The advancement of live-streaming technology allows concerts and events to reach global audiences.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Pandemic Will Have Lasting Effects on the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: During the extended period in lockdown, an ongoing demand for events and entertainment led many events to be hosted remotely. Moving forward, virtual and hybrid events will become an industry standard.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Activity Will Become Increasingly Digital
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since the pandemic, a significant portion of live event promotion has shifted to utilize online streaming platforms and social media websites.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Upgrades in Safety Measures Must Be Implemented
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As safety becomes a greater concern at live events, industry operators are anticipated to emphasize security infrastructure at venues moving forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Sustainability is a Growing and Essential Trend in the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers' growing environmental consciousness will drive demand for sustainable event options.

industry_definition: This industry creates, manages and promotes live performances and events, ranging from concerts and theater performances to state fairs and air shows. Some promoters lease space from stadium-, arena- and theater-owners, while others own and operate venues.
key_trends: Demand for live events has skyrocketed since COVID-19 lockdown measures ceased. This pent-up demand led to a strong recovery.
There have been significant labor shortages affecting promoters in recent years
The Save Our Stages Act was a US federal law passed in December 2020 as part of the COVID-19 relief package
Safety regulations include guidelines for crowd control, emergency response plans, proper equipment usage, and safe stage setup
The internet has become a powerful tool for music discovery
Concertgoers are most often between the ages of 25 and 54
Location is often determined by conditions like climate and consumer demand
Promoters find the most success operating in locations with many potential consumers

market_segmentation.segment_description: The bulk of industry events target this age group who tend to spend more discretionary income on live events than any other demographic. They are likely to allocate the most towards admissions, concessions and merchandise.

While they attend live events, theatrical and orchestral performances are more popular with this audience than concerts or sporting events. They do not draw as much advertising, food/beverage and merchandise revenue.
Similar to the 65 and older group, this demographic attends more theatrical and orchestral performances than concerts or sporting events and does not generate as much ancillary revenue.

This group attends all types of live performances and is a major revenue generator for merchandise and concessions, though ticket purchases are more common among slightly older populations with higher incomes.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Admission to Live Performing Arts Events
products_and_services.product_description: Includes live music performances at clubs, theaters, arenas, amphitheaters, music festivals, plays, musicals and operas. Attendance rises when consumer income and corporate profit are high to support acts. Artists use live events to generate revenue as album sales decline.
Other minor products and services offered by the industry.
Many smaller venues maintain contracted live performers to provide entertainment, often including dining options. Common for operators that own hotels, casinos and tourist establishments.
Includes admission to nonfranchise sporting events like boxing matches, rodeos, etc. Does not include franchised teams. Revenue needs to be supplemented with concession sales.
A significant portion of revenue for smaller venues that rely on these sales to cover payroll expenses. Large operators often contract these services to third parties.
Includes pushing information out, sponsorships from businesses as advertising, and negotiating with media outlets for exclusive coverage to drive viewership.
Revenue generated by renting venues to third parties and consumers directly, common for smaller venues and larger promoters renting for conferences, campaigns, etc.

tier_1_suppliers: Movie & Video Production in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US
Camera & Film Wholesaling in the US
Musical Groups & Artists in the US
tier_1_buyers: Performers & Creative Artists in the US
Musical Groups & Artists in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Attendance of concerts and events is closely linked with broader trends in US tourism. During periods of economic growth, increased domestic trips benefit the industry since individuals can afford to attend events outside local areas.

Industry establishments are located in distinct tourist destinations, so promoters benefit from an increase in international tourism. When visiting a destination, there is a higher propensity for spending on special outings like live events.

Household disposable income affected by interest rates, wages, taxes and employment can influence spending on discretionary items like concerts and events. Lower disposable income results in weaker demand.

The consumer confidence index indicates consumer attitudes, helpful in predicting behavior towards nonessential purchases like industry services. As confidence rises, so does spending on industry services.
Represents increasing internet use for services typically conducted in-person, indicating whether individuals are spending time inside or outside.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region of the United States.

The Mid-Atlantic region of the United States is home to several high-profile cities such as New York City and Philadelphia, both of which have a strong theatre scene. The highly concentrated populations in these cities make them ideal for concerts and other large events with high capacity.
The New England region of the United States.
The Plains region of the United States.
The Rocky Mountains region of the United States.

The Southeast region of the US is a lucrative area for event promoters and artists due to the profile of major cities in these areas. Many outdoor venues in the region can remain open throughout the year, maintaining that the Southeast will remain a lucrative area for event promoters and artists for many years.
The Southwest region of the United States.

The Western region of the US, especially California, is a cultural hub that attracts a variety of events and promoters due to its numerous metropolitan areas with diverse cultures, styles and climates. Like the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast, the West has one of the highest concentrated populations and is a coveted area for touring performers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: For most events promoters are required to secure permits or licenses in order to do things like play loud music or serve alcohol to attendees.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Skilled staff for event planning and logistics incur high costs, making it challenging for new entrants to compete with established firms and maintain profitability.

basis_points.basis_description: Fragmentation plays a big role in market concentration. There's a low level of market share concentration as there are many small players serving localized markets. Consolidation in the industry is rising. The largest players have been engaging in mergers and acquisitions in order to grow their market shares.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small promoters benefit from localized markets
concentration_points.concentration_description: Small promoters benefit from serving a localized market. An overwhelming majority of industry operators are classified as nonemploying companies, meaning they employ less than five individuals, and are overall much smaller than their largest competitors.

There is sufficient space for many promoters to compete in these highly localized regional markets; the US consists of many different kinds of communities, varying in population size and disposable income. There are differences in the types of entertainment individuals in a certain region are seeking, offering a variety of avenues for promoters to explore.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit has been experiencing growth in recent years, despite COVID-19 generating significant losses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The profitability of concert and event promotion is directly influenced by the level of purchase costs and wage spending, the two largest expense categories. A promoter's ability to attract high profile clients affects the potential size of events, as well as the level of ticket pricing.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGE ALLOCATION CAN FLUCTUATE BASED ON SEASONAL TRENDS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Employee compensation accounts for an estimated 19.4% of revenue in 2023 and is the second-largest expense in event promotion. Wage costs have increased from 17.2% in 2018, as allocation of funds towards wages increased substantially in 2020 amid the pandemic. Successful promoters are skilled in sales, marketing, event management, licensing and customer service. Often higher-level staff also maintain qualifications in law, finance and accounting. A promoter's personal reputation aids in attracting and retaining high-value clients, making good promoters a valuable financial asset.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASE COSTS ARE MADE UP OF THE PAYMENTS MADE TO AN EVENT'S SANCTIONING BODY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: This includes the venue's operational costs and the purchase of licensed merchandise, food and beverages sold at the event. Expenses will be higher for a small-scale independent venue that provides food and beverage services in house, versus contracting these services to third-party providers, as many large-scale operators do. These expenses account for an estimated 4.2% of revenue in 2023, up from 3.3% in 2018.

The purchase segment also accounts for corporate entertainment, travel and accommodation, in addition to some of the costs associated with producing events, such as casting auditions. At the highest level, success hinges on making and maintaining personal contacts. Company employees tend to travel extensively, entertain at the company's expense and use expensive technology to maintain contact and work schedules.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation is far higher for promoters that own venues and audiovisual equipment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation accounts for an estimated 2.7% of revenue in 2023. Competing enterprises that own facilities must maintain high-quality venues that meet all federal and state health, safety and disability standards laid out by federal law. As a way of boosting earnings, many operators utilize expensive lighting and audiovisual recording equipment to record shows, attract attendees and sell associated merchandise. In comparison with other expense categories, depreciation costs remain insignificant.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Promoters that operate their own facilities incur fewer rental costs than those without facilities
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Operators typically have to rent some equipment for the promoted events, which may include seating structures, merchandise stands and sound and lighting equipment. Geographic location tends to dictate rent expenses, as promoters located in highly populous areas will typically allocate larger portions of revenue toward rent in reward for higher foot-traffic. Rent is slated to make up 5.0% of industry revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Skilled staff for event planning and logistics incur high costs
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Skilled staff for event planning and logistics incur high costs, making it challenging for new entrants to compete with established firms and maintain profitability.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Promoters have to deal with inherent seasonality in their profession, since some events, such as large music festivals and specific sporting events cannot be held in an indoor venue. Outdoor sporting events and festivals occur predominantly from April through September, as these months are typically warmer in the United States. The summer concert season is popular with all age groups, and is important due to the great weather and the increased amount of free time.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Levels of Disposable Income and Time Available for Leisure
volatility_points.volatility_description: Concert and event-going can be a special sort of outing, as tickets are usually expensive and is not a priority for extremely busy individuals. Only with extraneous cash do people really allow themselves to indulge in extravagant outings. Under economic pressure, this is the first nonessential people give up. Events are most often planned months in advance and use collected admission revenue as funding. Thanks to the unprecedented disruptions generated by COVID-19, promoters struggled to maintain income despite many people having more time and money to spend.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ADMISSION TO LIVE PERFORMING ARTS EVENTS HAS INCREASED IN LINE WITH CONSUMERS' GROWING USE OF THE INTERNET AS A TOOL FOR MUSIC DISCOVERY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Includes live music performances at clubs, music theaters, arenas and amphitheaters, in addition to local and regional music festivals and theatrical performances, such as plays, musicals and operas. A rise in theatre attendance is expected when consumer income and corporate profit are high, both of which fuel donations to support many Broadway and off-Broadway acts. Since the shutdown in 2020, Broadway shows have returned to New York City with shows selling tickets for full-capacity theaters. Artists increasingly use live events to generate revenue as album sales continue to plummet.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Contracted Live Performances are a Reliable Source of Revenue
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many smaller-scale venues maintain contracted live performers in house to provide entertainment on a weekly basis. This is most common among operators that also own private hotels, casinos and other tourist establishments, like major industry operator Caesars Entertainment Corporation. These services aim to provide entertainment to enterprise guests in surrounding establishments and often include full-service dining options along with entertainment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Admission to Nonfranchise Sporting Events has Increased as Boxing and Mixed-Martial Arts (MMA) Gain Popularity
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nonfranchise sports, like boxing matches and rodeos are considered in this segment. It does not include sporting events pertaining to franchised teams, such as those in the NFL, MLB, NBA and NHL. Franchises in these leagues own and operate stadiums and any necessary outsourcing of the franchise's event promotions are performed by respective league offices. These events are generally inexpensive to attend so revenue earned from ticket sales needs to be heavily supplemented with concession sales.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Food, Beverage and Merchandise Sales are Significant Portion of Revenue for Smaller Venues
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Smaller venues that dictate smaller attendance levels rely on these sales to generate bonus revenue on an event and cover payroll expenses. Large-scale venue operators often contract these services to third-party providers and, therefore, do not benefit from the revenue of these sales.

FAQs.question: How much does your company rely on successful advertising to stand out from the competition? How does your company advertise?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators invest significantly into marketing to stand out. Paid promotions through internet sites and social media platforms can help reduce costs and reach a larger potential audience than traditional methods.

FAQs.question: Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: Since concerts and events are considered nonessential, the industry is highly sensitive to discretionary spending levels.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Industry events hosted in major cities and other highly populated areas are more likely to draw a large crowd and boost revenue.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use rental agreements to save on equipment expenses? Have you taken advantage of recent reductions in financing rates?
FAQs.answer: Many promoters elect to rent rather than buy facilities and equipment to save funds. Buying these items leads to higher margins down the line.

FAQs.question: Has your company integrated web and mobile reservation and appointment systems to improve consumer accessibility?
FAQs.answer: Many of the industry's largest players rely heavily on their websites and mobile applications in order increase consumer accessibility. Integrating customer service capabilities into these sites can also help reduce labor and administrative expenses.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: The advent of social media has allowed many small promoters to enter the industry, as promoters can easily spread the word about events through Facebook and Twitter.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Many of the industry's largest promoters have in-house compliance teams that allow them to ensure that they are up-to-date with regulatory changes.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: While some promoters offer membership agreements, most are too small to remain profitable while offering membership discounts.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin compare to industry average figures?
FAQs.answer: Company-specific profit margins above or below industry average figures generally implies pricing power or weakness.

FAQs.question: How can you maintain superior service while reducing operating costs?
FAQs.answer: Mergers and acquisitions are common within this industry as a technique to reduce operating costs while maintaining superior customer service.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue comes from non-ticket sales? What additional revenue streams have been most profitable? How has your company adapted to the pandemic environment?
FAQs.answer: Establishments must be able to diversify their revenue sources away from simply relying on admission fees. Additional revenue streams include concessions, merchandise, premium seating, artist services and rental income from venue leasing. Many venues are seeking new forms of revenue as ticket sales on events have plummeted amid the coronavirus pandemic. One example is virtual concert attendance.

FAQs.question: Does your company stay up to date with the latest technology? What value-added services do you offer that are facilitated by technology?
FAQs.answer: Larger industry players must take advantage of technology to appeal to performers, increase ticket sales, enhance the consumer experience and provide value-added offerings. Many promoters adopted event streaming services to prevent more substantial losses when in-person gatherings were highly restricted.

FAQs.question: How do you address trends and economic factors to make informed decisions in your business?
FAQs.answer: Maintaining a more flexible cost structure has proven crucial for sustaining business through the pandemic period.

FAQs.question: How do you anticipate the performance of domestic trips by US residents affecting the revenue and profitability of your business?
FAQs.answer: Domestic trips by US residents generally tracks domestic travel and tourism. As more people travel within the country, the opportunities to attend concerts and events in different cities and regions will increase.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in corporate profit? What percentage of your revenue is derived from ticket sales to corporate clients?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit is a useful indicator of industry success, as large companies often purchase corporate or premium seating at events to entertain clients. Moreover, companies with higher advertising budgets are likelier to sponsor and advertise at events.

FAQs.question: How is your business affected by changes in household disposable income? How has your company responded to recent volatility in per capita disposable income amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Household disposable income can influence demand for and expenditure on sporting and performing arts events held by industry operators. Since industry events are discretionary, lower per capita disposable income results in weaker demand.
